The inclusive/exclusive distinction is a common feature of the Teso group
within Eastern Nilotic. The first person plural inclusive form above embraces
'I and you', i.e. those participating in a Speech event, äs against the first
person plural exclusive form, which refers to 'I and somebody not participating in the Speech event', thereby excluding the addressee in the Speech act.

a language has gender categories in the noun, it has gender categories in the
pronoun' is contradicted in Turkana, and, therefore, requires further explanation. One possible explanation for this is the fact that in Turkana (and
Nilotic languages in general) pronouns are only used in those cases were ambiguity "would otherwise result, or in marked constructions due to topicalization or contrastive emphasis where the pronauns perform an anaphoric function (see chapters 7 and 8). Kenya in an area extending from the Sudan border, south and southeast to
the country of the Pokot, the Samburu and the Rendille, and from the border with Uganda eastwards äs far äs Lake Turkana (formerly Lake Rudolf).
The Turkana traditionally are predominantly pastoral herdsmen, who raise
cattle, sheep, goats and camels in hard climatic conditions. People living
in the northern and southern parts of the area also practice some agriculture. In more recent times, agricultural projects have been started throughout the area. Along Lake Turkana people also practise fishing, a means of
subsistence traditionally excluded, because of a taboo on fish-eating, äs
is the case with many East-African pastoralists (cf. Best, 1978).
The people call themseives /ni-turk(w)ana/ (singular: /e-turk(w)ana-it/) ,
and their language /na-turk(w)ana/. They call their country /turk(w)an'/
They are reasonably well known from anthropological descriptions, especially through studies by Gulliver (e.g. 1958, 1963, 1966). The oral tradition of the Turkana people äs well äs of related groups is presented in
Lamphear (1976). According to this tradition the Turkana and other groups
such äs the Karimojong all dispersed from the Koten area in northeastern
Uganda a few centuries ago. (A text dealing with the oral tradition of the
Turkana has been included at the end of this grammar.) The later, colonial'
history of the Turkana people is described in Barber (1968). More recently, Fedders and Salvadori (1977) have written an illustrated study of Turkana craftsmen.
The exact number of Speakers of Turkana is not known. According to the
Kenya Population Census of 1969 (Ministry of Finance and Econpmic Planning,
Nairobi) there were 203,177 native Speakers in that year, most of whom lived
in the Turkana district of Kenya. Others lived in the western part of the
Samburu district, äs well äs in Isiolo district, mainly in and around Isiolo town. The area inhabited by the Turkana probably is still expanding. More
recently, Turkana people have settled in and around Kitale (see also map).
Heine (1980:32) estimates their number at around 220,000. Some governmentofficials have stated more recently that the figure of 250.000 or even beyond may be more accurate. (For details of second language use and other
sociolinguistic aspects of Turkana see Whiteley (1974:13-68)).
The Turkana area is divided into territorial sections which seem to be
related to the migration and expansion of various Turkana groups over the
last few centuries (Lamphear, 1968). The borders are rather fluent, especially in the north across the Sudan border, where the Turkana share dry season
pastures with the Toposa and Nyangatom, who are also pastoralists. Some Turkana people stay permanently in the Ilemi triangle, which is formed by the
borders of Kenya, Sudan and Ethiopia. This area is Sudanese territory, but
is presently under Kenyan administration. In this area the Turkana compete
for grazing grounds with the Toposa and Nyangatom äs well äs with the (Cushitic) Dasanetch, who are known äs Marille (/ni -mar^-le/) to the Turkana. Thepresenting a general overview of the language, with specific questions being
treated in more detail, because they pose special problems for the field of
Nilotic studies and because they are particularly complicated. Such problems
are: gender, case, number, the verb morphology and word order.

55Chapter 3The noun phrase(s) bear(s) a specific semantic (or case) relation to the
verb. The semantic role is not an inherent property of the noun phrase, butSentence Structureis part of the composition plan of the verb. The type of semantic roles needed
is presented in the section following this one. The case relations are built
on top of an explicit categorial framework consisting of a verb (V) and one
or more noun phrases (NP's). The positions of syntactic constituents like
subject, direct object and indirect object in a sentence are determined by the3.1. The notion basic sentence
The term 'basic sentence' can be looked at from at least two points of view:
(a) From the point of view of 'pragmatics', in that a specific sentence
is marked for a certain context in which it can be used. With regard
to basic sentences, unmarked for any context, a distinction can be
made between simple (or 'kernel', or 'atomic') sentences, and 'extended' (or 'compiex') ones. The latter are more complex from a syn-semantic roles performed by these constituents, äs shown in section 3.7.
Verbs, furthermore, have inherent semantic features. They are either action
verbs, process verbs or Stative verbs. These inherent properties are discussed

verb-prominent language, i.e. the verb is the central element of the sentence.

No Claim is made here that the presentation of the basic sentence structure of Turkana in this grarnmar corresponds to any deep structure level of
the language. It is probably more accurate to call it 'shallow structure'.
The latter does not necessarily represent the abstract underlying structure.
Its purpose is simply to present a framework that makes it possible to refer
basic and derived sentences in a unified way.
Complex sentences tend to have a less elaborate System of tense and aspectual distinctions. They also tend to be more conservative from a diachronic
point of view. Thus, to take one example, with negation in complex verbal
sentences in Turkana the old Niio-Saharan negative marker {ma-} only occurs
in a restricted environment (see section 9.2.6.) . Core sentences tend to
have a more elaborate System of negation distinctions. These core sentences,
therefore, are more innovative. Given the historical-comparative purpose of
this grammar, the distinctions drawn above thus also provide a frame of reference for the historical dynamism of the various grammatical aspects treated.
This study does not follow any specific syntactic or morphological theory,
although an attempt has been made to present a clear-cut sentence structure.
The author has been influenced by ideas expressed in Case grammar äs developed
by Pillmore and others (see e.g. Fillmore (1968, 1971, 1976), R. M. Newman
(1971)), Furthermore, Functional grammar äs developed by Dik (1978, 1980) has
been influential. As a model of language it is very much like Case grammar.
For some points of convergence and divergence see e.g. Lachlan Mackenzie
(1980). The main advantage of such modeis is that there is no assumption of
a sequence 'NP VF' (or 'VP NP'), or 'NP Predicate phrase'. For a verb-initial
language like Turkana this would imply an ad hoc transformation moving the
initial (subject) noun phrase into a Position following the verb. Such a
transformation may be required 'in a deep-structure analysis of the language,of the syntactic configuration developed along the lines of Chomsky (1965),
since the constituents belonging to the verb-phrase (VP) are discontinuous
in Turkana, at least in surface structures with VSO word order. As both VSO
and VOS word order occur, the subject function, which is explicitly marked
in Turkana, cannot be determined on the basis of its position with regard
to the verb. This means that recourse is to be taken to other notions, in
order to be able to determine and predict the syntactic functions of noun
phrases which are explicitly marked.
The Turkana data suggest that semantic roles o£ noun phrases are relevant i
word order .Semantic roles are probably best studied within the framework
of Case grammar and of Functional grammar. As stated above, the main advantage of these modeis is that there is no assumption of a strict 'NP VP'
(or 'VP NP') order in the base. The lack of a clear-cut syntactic framework
in these modeis is probably also one of their weaknesses. The position taken
by the author of this grammar is that both a clear-cut syntactic framework,
äs well äs semantic notions like Ägentive are needed in order to account for
a verb-initial language like Turkana. In comparing Turkana with another verbinitial language which belongs to the Southern Nilotic branch of Nilotic,

A widespread feature of Nilotic languages is the use of what is called here
the subsecutive mood. This verb form mainly occurs in Subordinate clauses,
or the second of two co-ordinated clauses. Crazzolara (1933) has described
this verb type for Nuer, a Western Nilotic language. Höre recently, Noonan
and Bavin (1981) have described the syntax and semantics of this verb construction for Lango, another Western Nilotic language.
The subsecutive mood with verbs differs from the indicative in a number
of ways, at least in the affirmative:
(a) Tense marking is absent. Although most often the verb has past tense
meaning, äs can be grasped from the context (see various examples below), this is not explicitly indicated. In the closely related lan-tion see Tucker and Mpaayei (1955:53).
(b) The specific set of agreement markers is completely different from the
set found with the indicative, conditional, exclamative or subjunctivesingulara-to-a-a-to-ki-ki-to-to-kl-kl-forms, in order to keep it distinct from the first person Singular. Whenever
a first person Singular or plural functions äs a direct object or indirect
object, and a third person occurs äs the subject, the marker {k-} is prefixed to these first person prefixes, but not to the second person prefixes.
